conclusion: Object A drives into several groups of colored blocks to determine which blocks it will collide with and where it will stop.

In the first image, there are several stacks of colored blocks on a green surface: a blue stack (3 blocks), an orange stack (2-3 blocks), a red stack (3 blocks), a green stack (3 blocks of different sizes), and a single yellow block at the bottom. Object A is visible at the right edge of the image, indicated by a red arrow.

In the second image, Object A has moved into the arrangement and appears to have collided primarily with orange blocks. The orange blocks show the most disruption, having been knocked over and displaced. The blue, red, green, and yellow blocks appear to remain in roughly their original positions. Object A has come to rest among the orange blocks.
Object A had enough momentum to disrupt the orange stack completely but did not have enough power or the right trajectory to significantly affect the other colored stacks.
Object A appears to have directly impacted the orange blocks, transferring enough energy to scatter them, while the other block stacks were outside its direct path.

After colliding with the orange blocks, Object A's momentum was absorbed by the collision, causing it to stop among the scattered orange blocks. There is no visible evidence of significant deflection to other block groups.

Object A collided primarily with the orange blocks, causing them to scatter. The collision absorbed Object A's momentum, causing it to stop among the disrupted orange blocks. The blue, red, green, and yellow blocks remained largely undisturbed because they were outside Object A's direct path.
